content: Hello everybody. My name is Mark and i'm 33 years old in June. I work for the U.S Post Office and have been there for 10 years going on 11. I feel that there are bigger and better opportunities out there for me as well as my FAMILY. I've been thinking about enlisting into the Airforce Reserves for a while now because i've heard about alot of benefits that I think would benefit ME. As great as that may sound, I am more interested in how my 3 boys and my wife can benefit from this. Basically my main question is: By me enlisting, does uncle Sam help me pay for my boys education and possibly my wifes education? I have an 11 year old going on 12 in July, a 3 year old going on 4 in August, and a four month old. My wife is 31 and their future is my concern. I am willing to do and sacrifice anything for them!
reply: Hello everybody. My name is Mark and i'm 33 years old in June. I work for the U.S Post Office and have been there for 10 years going on 11. Basically my main question is: By me enlisting, does uncle Sam help me pay for my boys education and possibly my wifes education? I have an 11 year old going on 12 in July, a 3 year old going on 4 in August, and a four month old. My wife is 31 and their future is my concern. I am willing to do and sacrifice anything for them!
title: How does my 3 boys and wife benefit from me joining Airforce Reserves

content: quote: Originally posted by familyfirst: Hello everybody. My name is Mark and i'm 33 years old in June. I work for the U.S Post Office and have been there for 10 years going on 11. I feel that there are bigger and better opportunities out there for me as well as my FAMILY. I've been thinking about enlisting into the Airforce Reserves for a while now because i've heard about alot of benefits that I think would benefit ME. As great as that may sound, I am more interested in how my 3 boys and my wife can benefit from this. Basically my main question is: By me enlisting, does uncle Sam help me pay for my boys education and possibly my wifes education? I have an 11 year old going on 12 in July, a 3 year old going on 4 in August, and a four month old. My wife is 31 and their future is my concern. I am willing to do and sacrifice anything for them! If your still here, follow this: I was 10 years into a Teaching and Coaching career, making about $15,000.00 a year working from daylight to dark (6 classes a day, the football, wrestling, tennis,and track after school), and the community swimming pool (0700-2100 Mon-Sat). A relative talked me into going into the Air Guard (similar), and taking a commission. I was never seeing my wife and 4 sons anyway, except when they came to events or the pool , so I decided to give up the extra-curricular involvement and go for it. After the third year, I was bringing in as much as $20,000.00 extra a year, by doing night duty and extended TDY deployments in the summer (This was in the 80s before Desert Storm). In other words, I often better than doubled my civilian income. I got back in Uniform (I'd been in the Army), where I really felt at home, and I did some things (especially on Drug Interdiction missions "points south") that I felt really made a GOOD difference. Because I remained a High School teacher, I promoted Patriotism there, often taking part in Patriotic Veterans Day Assemblies and such. I often inspired students to enter all branches of the Services. Two are attending West Point helped by my letters of recommendation. And best of all, my Service had an extremely positive affect on both my marriage and my boys. My wife, whom I have treated with great respect for 40 years, backed me like the Rock of Gibraltar; and my boys have turned out to be hard-charging, good young men. I can't guarantee you will have such a great experience, but it's there to go after!! Pick a good job, and go for it!!! Me, the boys, Mystical, and some spouses to boot!! Wandering and Wondering

content: quote: Me, the boys, Mystical, and some spouses to boot!! GWG, I'm always in awe of your family when you post that picture. One picture is truly worth a thousand words. But, I'll have one that comes close in a couple of months. When my wife puts on her old AF uniform, me in my old army uniform, my SIL in his old CG uniform, my daughter and one of my granddaughter's in their CG uniforms and another one of my granddaughters in her new AF uniform. I'm so excited about it - I can hardly stand it. I asked the AF granddaughter (now in AF BMT) why she didn't choose the CG or the Army. She said, grandpa I love you and mom, but I don't want to compete with either of you. I know they say the WW2 generation was the greatest generation. But, I think this generation, in service right now, is second-to-none. God and the soldier, All men adore, In time of trouble, And no more; For when war is over, And all things righted, God is neglected - The old soldier slighted. Founding Member Original DVG & Proud Member, Rupterd Duck/Derelict Veterans

Then skip the reserves and go AD. The bennefits are better and pays more than an extra 100 bucks a months. Working for USPS for that long you're prolly making approx $40 a year before taxes? Active duty just starting out you'll make almost $38K walking into the uniform. I fiigured you as an E3 base pay (sign for 6 years and you would be), plus BAH & BAS Can't beat that w/ a stick just starting anywhere.

content: quote: Originally posted by familyfirst: Hello everybody. My name is Mark and i'm 33 years old in June. I work for the U.S Post Office and have been there for 10 years going on 11. I feel that there are bigger and better opportunities out there for me as well as my FAMILY. I've been thinking about enlisting into the Airforce Reserves for a while now because i've heard about alot of benefits that I think would benefit ME. As great as that may sound, I am more interested in how my 3 boys and my wife can benefit from this. Basically my main question is: By me enlisting, does uncle Sam help me pay for my boys education and possibly my wifes education? I have an 11 year old going on 12 in July, a 3 year old going on 4 in August, and a four month old. My wife is 31 and their future is my concern. I am willing to do and sacrifice anything for them! Couple of thoughts after reading your post and the replies that you got. A) Scroll down to the Air Force section and then look for the Guard & Reserve sub-section. Post your questions there. Ask the local Recruiter some questions and read the brochures. B) Talk with your wife. You already have a steady civilian job as a Postal Worker. If you sign-up for the AF Reserve you will have to attend Basic Training which is now about 7-8 weeks at Lackland AFB in Texas. Can she handle the housework/pay the bills/buy-shop for groceries/get the older boy to school and take care of the smaller boys/take them to the doctor-dentist/add a quart of oil to the car...? For 2 months ? By herself ? Then after you graduate Basic Training at Lackland, you are sent to whatever Tech (job) school that your Reseerve Unit has a vacancy for... Tech school can be a month to 6 months long, depending on the difficulty level of the course/task. Is she going to be able to handle "things" and situations while you are away ? Talk to her and ask HER what she thinks. Many women want their husbands at home with them and the kids. Save yourself a ton of grief and heartache. Get the Recruiter to sit down and answer her questions, if you proceed. After Tech School, then you return to your Home of record and the next Drill Weekend you get over to the AF Reserve Base/Center and report in. Usually about 0700 hrs Saturday until about 1630 hrs. Sunday. Once a month. That means you may miss birthday parties of relatives/weddings/Little League games,Cub Scout stuff, Sunday Church service etc... 2 weeks a year you and the Unit do annual Training. Could be at the nearest Air Base to your Home, or you could be sent overseas for training. Then there is something that you and your wife REALLY need to talk about: It is called Activation... nope not the Cell phone kind, I'm talking about your unit gets a notice that says you are Activated and will be going overseas for a tour... usually at least 6 months. Can your wife handle you being gone for 6 months ? You need to do some thinking and talking, before you become a statistic of the Divorce desease. If it sounds like I'm trying to talk you out of joining--- you are correct. Why ? Because your Thread Title and you question are ALL WRONG! The "benefits" are NOT why anyone should sign-up. They are just that "benefits". The reason for joining any branch of the Armed Forces should NOT be job training or worse "college" money... or "benefits". The Reason for joining is to protect and defend The Constitution of the United States of America from all enemies Foriegn and Domestic! If you are not of that mindset, then stay at the Post Office and be a dad to your kids, and a husband to your wife.
